properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of wet snow continue this morning. Snow across the region will gradually tapering off late this morning with additional snowfall amounts up to 5 cm possible. The snow may continue until the early afternoon between Timmins and the Quebec border however significant amounts are not expected this afternoon. Untreated surfaces may become slippery. Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-31T01:18:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-30T09:19:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0704626142.2020
Area: Timmins - Cochrane - Iroquois Falls
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Spring is on hold, and central Albertans are encouraged to remain home. Heavy snow will begin this evening, with total accumulations of 10 to 15 cm possible by Tuesday morning. A moisture-rich weather system will move across the province tonight. It is likely that this storm will produce significant snowfall over much of east-central Alberta. At this time, the greatest confidence in the highest accumulations is for areas east of the city of Edmonton. However, there remains a moderate likelihood of at least 10 cm falling elsewhere. Once there is increased certainty on forecast amounts more regions may be added to the snowfall warning in effect. Temperatures will be well below normal this week. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-31T02:44:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-30T10:45:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3410697827.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow continues today. Conditions are favourable for heavy snow to continue over the Coquihalla highway today. 5 to 10 cm of snow has been reported at some locations along the highway this morning. Total accumulations up to 25 cm can be expected by this evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-31T09:07:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-30T17:08:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1789009742.2020
Area: Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain on the way for mid week. Rainfall totals: 15 to 35 mm. Location: northern and eastern Nova Scotia including Cape Breton. Time span: Wednesday and Thursday Remarks: Rain will begin on Wednesday morning as a warm front passes westward through the Gulf of St. Lawrence and into New Brunswick. This rain could persist through the day on Thursday. Heaviest rainfall amounts are expected along the eastern shore of Nova Scotia and eastern Cape Breton Island. The rain, combined with mild temperatures may cause significant melting of any remaining snowpack and runoff. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-31T10:57:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-30T18:58:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3260761176.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow beginning Tuesday morning changing to rain Wednesday morning. Snowfall total: 2 to 5 cm. Rainfall total: 15 to 30 mm except possibly exceeding 40 mm over Prince County. Location: Prince Edward Island. Remarks: A warm front moving westward through the Gulf of St. Lawrence will bring a few cm of snow to the Island beginning early Tuesday morning. As temperatures rise behind the front, precipitation will change to rain on Wednesday morning and persist into Thursday. Temperatures will remain above freezing even during the overnight hours on Wednesday. The rain and mild temperatures may lead to significant melting of the snow pack and runoff. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-31T10:57:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-30T18:58:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0552682431.2020
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I., Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow beginning Tuesday afternoon changing to rain Wednesday. Snowfall total: 2 to 5 cm. Rainfall total: 15 to 35 mm except possibly exceeding 40 mm in the northeast. Location: eastern New Brunswick. Remarks: A warm front moving westward off the Gulf of St. Lawrence will bring a few cm of snow to New Brunswick beginning Tuesday afternoon. Precipitation will change to rain on Wednesday as temperatures rise above zero. An extended period of rain is then expected to last until Thursday night, when temperatures should fall below zero again. At this time, precipitation should change to flurries and taper off by Friday morning. Temperatures will remain above freezing through the overnight hours on Wednesday. The rain and mild temperatures could lead to significant melting of the snow pack and runoff. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-31T10:57:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-30T18:58:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3840355313.2020

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Northwest winds of 50 gusting 70 km/h today are causing poor visibilities due to blowing snow at Hall Beach and Igloolik. Blizzard conditions with visibilities generally less than 400 metres will persist until some time this evening after which time the winds will start diminishing and visibilities improving. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-31T07:59:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-30T18:06:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2734012861.2020
Area: Hall Beach, Igloolik

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm continues. A prolonged period of snowfall continues to impact communities in northern Manitoba, with another 5 to 10 cm expected to accumulate tonight. While snow from this first system will gradually taper off later tonight, a second disturbance is expected to cross northwestern sections of the province Tuesday night into Wednesday, potentially bringing another 10 to 15 cm of snow to those areas. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A weather system moving in from southern Alberta will spread snow into west-central Saskatchewan around midnight. Snow will then push eastward across the northern grainbelt on Tuesday. Southern and east-central Saskatchewan however will experience mostly rain with this system, although some areas will change over to flurries as colder air comes in behind the system. There is also a risk of freezing rain overnight and Tuesday morning through the Kindersley, Saskatoon, Melfort, North Battleford and Prince Albert areas. Snowfall totals in the Meadow Lake region will be in the 10 to 15 cm range, with about 5 to 10 cm forecast from North Battleford through Prince Albert, then lesser amounts further south. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-31T13:41:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-30T21:42:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1708388348.2020
Area: R.M. of Meadow Lake including Waterhen Res., R.M. of Beaver River including Pierceland and Goodsoil, Green Lake, R.M. of Loon Lake including Loon Lake and Makwa, R.M. of Big River including Big River and Chitek Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 10 cm is expected. 10 cm of snow is forecast to fall today as a sharp front crosses the Lake District. The most favoured areas to receive the heavy snow are communities between Burns Lake and Fraser Lake. The heavy snow will end this evening as the front passes. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-31T04:02:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-30T18:03:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1771103676.2020
Area: Lakes District
